DataElement.preferredName: Cytokine Release Syndrome Hypotension Attribution Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The Cytokine Release Syndrome (CRS) description for the participant's hypotension (not attributable to any other cause).

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A syndrome that occurs after therapeutic infusion of antibodies into the blood and is characterized by nausea, headache, tachycardia, hypotension, rash, and shortness of breath. It is caused by the release of cytokines from the cells that are targeted by the antibodies. Most patients experience a mild to moderate reaction; however, the reaction may be severe and life-threatening._Blood pressure that is abnormally low.:To assign to a cause or source.

Most patients experience a mild to moderate reaction; however, the reaction may be severe and life-threatening._Blood pressure that is abnormally low.

Arginine-vasopressin (9 aa, ~1 kDa) is encoded by the human AVP gene. This protein is involved in peripheral blood vessel vasoconstriction and antidiuretic action in the kidney.
